data.message:
When you create games you can look at it as if you are directing movies.

This is the scene of a movie. Or a scene in your game.

And those are Actors. Which will be Actors in the game as well.

To put it into perspective for the boulder dash game

This is a scene with our hero and an enemy

I did not like the white background therefor I added a background image.

Makes it look like a game already

Its a pretty boring game, just those two actors standing there.

And that is because the game is missing some notion of time

To make the game come alive, you need to add some notion of time

A very simplistic one is this, update the game, and then sleep for some time

And keep doing that forever

Code samples with white background are pseudo code in a C like style



This update function will be called once a second.

In which you will then update your game state.

The game moves very slow and we can fix that to lower the sleep time.

17 milliseconds will give us about 60 updates per second

Now we are not really calling update every 17ms.

We forgot to take into account the time it took to run `update`

If update takes about 10ms then together with sleep we only call update about once in the 27ms

You can fix that by subtracting the time it took from the sleep

Another option would be to check how much time has passed since the last update

And use that as some kind of delta time in update

Than within update you check how much actors must move based on the delta time

An disadvantage of this is that too much time might have passed. And actor might jump pass walls

A safer bet is to have a stable update call. Which makes it unable for your game to make giant jumps on slow computers

If you split the update and view. You can do multiple update ticks in case too much time has passed the last loop.

To let the game `catch up`. At the cost of drawing the game less frequent. Which we will see as "frame drops"

But at least the hero did not cheat by running past a wall

Elm is a pure functional language and asking for the time is an impure operation.

Time has this habit of changing a lot

In order to get some time information you need to setup something called "Subscriptions"

Which allows mechanisms outside of your app to send `Messages` which you can handle in a pure fashion.

We define a message, setup a subscription to get that message every 17 milliseconds

And handle the message

We are running in the browser and the browser has some mechanism to redraw the screen.

And to make animations look smoother we can kinda hook into that redraw mechanism

We can do something similar as we did with time but then based on the browsers animation frame

This time we get the amount of milliseconds passed instead of a "stable 17ms" like we had with time

And therefor we should be doing some math instead of calling the update function everytime

You do not have for loops in Elm but we can create a List of a certain length and iterate over it

Which we do with List.repeat

We determine how often the 17ms has passed and create a list of the same length

Because we need to update the game based on the previous update. We can fold over our list and use our model as the accumulator

This will give us the sketched game loop

We can improve the game loop by limiting the amount of updates per "view".

We do this to not make it look like our hero jumped far because of a game hickup

This is easy by just taking x elements from our repeated list
Finally we should keep track of how many time we had left. Like 3ms if the timeSinceLast was 20ms.

After the `update` function returned our new model, elm will call our view function again

In which we will render the game

You will have actors for about everything in the game

Like we have a Hero and an Enemy

Which both have an `update` function.

Which should be called from the main loop

You add all the behaviours in those classes like walking and collection diamonds for our hero.

And walking and killing heroes for the enemy

After a while you will end up with more and more actors

Like a butterfly, which is an AI just like our Enemy but then being super cute instead of trying to kill the hero

This goes on and on and you end up with lots of actors which update functions get really big and messy

Also you will notice you get lots of duplicate behaviour among your actors.

A solution in the object oriented world could be to introduce some form of inheritance

Which is actually not really reusable and might give us "Diamonds of deaths"

Like I have no clue how this update function would look like

Another more reusable approach would be to put the behavior in separate places, which we called components here

And assign components to actors. Like our hero has the WalkComponent and CollectComponent or whatever

And we would give our enemy the KillComponent.

This way we can easily mix and match components and thereby create new actors with less effort

The benefits of Composition over Inheritance

This is nice because we do not have inheritance in Elm anyway hehe

Elm can do the composition which we call the Actor Component system in game programming

In Elm we can create our own type which we call Component

And Component can by any of those specified options

Its a bit like an Enum.

Components can hold data like we give a String to TagComponent to represent the tag name

And its can also have custom type or type aliases. Like we create some TransformComponentData record with x and y positions for the transform.

Once we have our components we can mix and match them to create actors.

We define an actor as just a list of components and we create our hero and enemy.

Now a little sidetrack

ControllerInputComponent and WalkAiComponent kinda do the same thing. They control the actors movement etc

Those components just do it in their own way, via collected input or some ai logic

We could group them together under one ControlComponent to make it clearer that you should not have both

Also you can keep giving data to your types like we give some AiSettings to ControlType

Constructing those components would then look like this

You could still add the same component type with different settings off course

But there is no helping against yourself mechanism here

Types in Elm are just data. They are not like objects which can have function and behaviour

In other words, our components do not do anything yet.

We need to add functions for their behaviours

Now the fun stuff begins

Here we have a very naive walking implementation for the WalkAiComponent

Which will just make the actor move to the right

We receive the actor that holds this component and we will need to fetch the transformComponent from the actor

Because the transform holds its current position

After that we will walk one position to the right. Which will create a new transform component

Which in turn needs to overwrite the current transform component of the actor

Finally if the actor did not have a transform component then we will return the actor as we received it
This function will try to get the TransformComponentData from the actor. But he might not have any therefor we return a Maybe.

walkRight will just create a new TransformData based on the current one but with x increased by one

Affectively moving the actor one position to the right

After that we need to update the actors transform component which we do by removing the old one and adding the new one

This concludes the behaviour of the component

but we still need to invoke it

Every game tick we would like to iterate over the actors to glue the actor component system with the main loop.

Because components can change their actor we need to do some folding

We fold over all the actors and let them call updateActor on each

Then we call the corresponding update for all components on the actor

Those components might have changed the actor therefor we need to update the actor in the accumulator, which is the list of actors

I have added the actors to our model

That way we can update the actors each game tick

Give that `updateActors` function the actors and store the updated actors with the rest of our model, forming a new model



This will actually work and we now have actors moving to the right which have that WalkAiComponent

It might look like a lot of work but I can tell you.... It will get worse

The kill component will find al neighbor actors and remove them from ehhh

Remove them from where?

To be able to do that we would need to give them the actors

Adding another level of folding in our main loop
To better show how the folding goes
Or you can control the hero manually

There is no logic in the code that we can just move our hero. Its all in the components

We should as well be able to move all actors
I actually meant all actors. Wall are are actors too

If you are getting the hand of this component system

Then you can make all sorts of things

You can watch game of life

With game of life all "cells" base their decision on the same version of the field

Which is an easy in with immutable data, you can just hold on to the level as it was before the game tick

You can also solve days 15 challenge of advent of code from previous year

Where goblins and elves where fighting each other and you had to calculate some score
And that answer was correct.

The components we created are just types. They are just data.

And data is serializable

This simplifies tuning and changing the game

This is a screen shot from the secret enemy we just saw

Not only can we configure the actors and their behaviour

But we can do that for the scene as well

And because our game is now in a serializable format

We can use or create other tools to simplify the creation of that format even more

Like there is this little level builder where you can create your own levels
Which you then upload and share on github!

In Elm deserialization this is not really interesting

Its just a big file with json decoders

There are plenty of articles online how to decode a json in elm

We have not talked about rendering yet but its surprisingly easy.

The rendering is about 400 lines of code which is not that much compared to the 7500 of code the whole game is.

Luckily for me because I changed "output engine" a few times already

After that came the Canvas renderer. Which looked the same as the game looks now

But it had two issues. One is performace, I had to redraw the whole scene every frame from scratch

Or came up with some awesome algorithm to reduce the amount of drawings needed or something

And problem two was that a technique used by the canvas library was deprecated and got removed in elm 0.19

The third time I wrote it with Svg which outperformed canvas insanely

When I was using canvas I configured the game at 12 fps

And you still had frame drops on mobile

And currently with svg it can hit 60fps

I still recreate all the visible actors as result of the `view` function

But between frames mostly only a few svg elements really changed

Elm runtime or the browser can take advantage of that html nodes did not change

Code wise all you have to do is create a new component which holds your rendering information

Like pixel color, images etc

And the Elm architecture already provided us with a view function

Where we can call the svg level rendering giving it information about the level

There you just iterate over the actors and create svg elements

We are going to have a little sidetrack again. This sidetrack was not planned for the talk.

Yesterday I attended the workshop of Nikolai which was about Augmented Reality in Haskell.
The augment reality part was handled by the javascript library called A-Frame

And the cool thing about A-Frame is that you just create html elements.

Which the library than transforms into the 3d space.

These html elements is the same idea that svg uses.

What I meant to say is: What about a VR renderer powered by A-Frame.

And on your mobile you will actually get the two screens.

And the bridge from Virtual Reality towards Augmented Reality is not that far.

And this is even more awesome on the mobile

I have to admit, I need to work on the controls a bit.

And also this is kinda useless, but so is the whole project

That was the end of the sidetrack.

Lets continue with the last mayor chapter which is performance

How to make sure the game actually runs at a decent frame rate.

One optimization we already discussed, which was using a better renderer.
And that is what we call the Game Loop
Now if we let the actors move one tile each update then that will look like this

Remembering our game loop. We would like to update on a stable 17 millisecond.

For as many 17 milliseconds since we did our last loop

If we build the actor component system nicely then you can easily create an enemy that disguises as a pet

But sometimes his "disguise" weirs off

The first renderer was this ascii renderer

Which maybe I should reintroduce
